description: From Middle English pelen itself from Old English pilian and Old French peler, pellier, both from Latin pilō, pilāre (“to remove hair from, depilate”), from pilus (“hair”). Doublet of pill.

entries.meaning: (usually uncountable) The skin or outer layer of a fruit, vegetable, etc.
(countable, rugby) The action of peeling away from a formation.
(countable) A cosmetic preparation designed to remove dead skin or to exfoliate.

verbs.description: peel (third-person singular simple present peels, present participle peeling, simple past and past participle peeled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove the skin or outer covering of.
examples: I sat by my sister's bed, peeling oranges for her.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove something from the outer or top layer of.
examples: I peeled (the skin from) a banana and ate it hungrily.
We peeled the old wallpaper off in strips where it was hanging loose.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become detached, come away, especially in flakes or strips; to shed skin in such a way.
examples: I had been out in the sun too long, and my nose was starting to peel.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To remove one's clothing.
examples: The children peeled by the side of the lake and jumped in.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move, separate (off or away).
examples: The scrum-half peeled off and made for the touchlines.

description: From Middle English peel, pele, from Anglo-Norman pel (compare modern French pieu), from Latin pālus (“stake”). Doublet of pole and pale.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A stake.
(obsolete) A fence made of stakes; a stockade.
(archaic) A small tower, fort, or castle; a keep.

description: From Middle English pele, from Old French pele (modern French pelle), from Latin pāla, from the base of plangere (“fix, plant”). Doublet of pala.

entries.meaning: A shovel or similar instrument, now especially a pole with a flat disc at the end used for removing pizza or loaves of bread from a baker's oven.
A T-shaped implement used by printers and bookbinders for hanging wet sheets of paper on lines or poles to dry.
(archaic, US) The blade of an oar.
(Scotland, curling) An equal or match; a draw.
(curling) A takeout which removes a stone from play as well as the delivered stone.

verbs.description: peel (third-person singular simple present peels, present participle peeling, simple past and past participle peeled)

entries.meaning: (curling) To play a peel shot.

description: Named from Walter H. Peel, a noted 19th-century croquet player.

verbs.description: peel (third-person singular simple present peels, present participle peeling, simple past and past participle peeled)

entries.meaning: (croquet) To send through a hoop (of a ball other than one's own).

verbs.description: peel (third-person singular simple present peels, present participle peeling, simple past and past participle peeled)

entries.meaning: (archaic, transitive) To plunder; to pillage, rob.
Alternative form of peal (“a small or young salmon”)
Misspelling of peal: to sound loudly.
examples: Oh ! still for me let merry bells peel out their holy chime;
